baseline_concepts.Lease Accounting: ASC 840 requires operating leases to be treated as off-balance sheet arrangements. Lessees recognize rent expense on straight-line basis over lease term. No asset or liability recognition for operating leases.
baseline_concepts.Revenue Recognition: ASC 605 requires revenue to be recognized when earned and realizable. Four criteria: persuasive evidence of arrangement, delivery occurred, price is fixed/determinable, collectibility is reasonably assured.
baseline_concepts.Right-of-Use Asset: Not applicable under ASC 840 operating lease model. Concept introduced in ASC 842.
baseline_concepts.Credit Losses: Incurred loss model for credit impairments. Losses recognized when probable that amount will not be collected. Historical loss experience primary input.
baseline_concepts.Lease Liability: Not recognized for operating leases under ASC 840. Only capital lease obligations on balance sheet.
baseline_concepts.Contract Asset: Not defined under ASC 605. Concept introduced with ASC 606 revenue standard.

current_concepts_high_drift.Lease Accounting: ASC 842 requires lessees to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for all leases (including operating leases) on balance sheet. Dual model retained for income statement purposes.
current_concepts_high_drift.Revenue Recognition: ASC 606 establishes five-step model: identify contract, identify performance obligations, determine transaction price, allocate price to obligations, recognize revenue when obligation satisfied.
current_concepts_high_drift.Right-of-Use Asset: Represents lessee's right to use underlying asset during lease term. Measured at initial measurement of lease liability plus initial direct costs, prepayments, less incentives.
current_concepts_high_drift.Credit Losses: CECL (Current Expected Credit Loss) model requires forward-looking estimates. Losses recognized at inception based on lifetime expected losses. Incorporates reasonable/supportable forecasts.
current_concepts_high_drift.Lease Liability: Present value of lease payments not yet paid, discounted using rate implicit in lease or incremental borrowing rate. Recognized for all leases under ASC 842.
current_concepts_high_drift.Contract Asset: Entity's right to consideration in exchange for goods/services transferred to customer. Differs from receivable (unconditional right to payment).

current_concepts_low_drift.Lease Accounting: ASC 840 requires operating lease arrangements to be off-balance sheet. Straight-line rent expense recognition over term.
current_concepts_low_drift.Credit Losses: Incurred loss model for credit loss impairments. Recognition when probable collection will not occur.

sample_documents.content: Lease accounting under ASC 842 requires lessees to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for substantially all leases on the balance sheet. This represents a significant change from ASC 840.

Revenue recognition follows ASC 606 five-step model. Step 1: Identify contract. Step 2: Identify performance obligations. Step 3: Determine transaction price. Step 4: Allocate price. Step 5: Recognize revenue.

Right-of-use asset represents the lessee's right to use an underlying asset during the lease term. Initial measurement equals lease liability plus initial direct costs and prepaid lease payments, less lease incentives.

CECL (Current Expected Credit Loss) model requires financial institutions to estimate lifetime expected credit losses at inception. This contrasts with the incurred loss model which recognized losses only when probable.

Lease liability equals the present value of lease payments not yet paid, discounted using the rate implicit in the lease or the lessee's incremental borrowing rate. Remeasured when lease modifications occur.
Under ASC 840 operating lease model, lessees recognize rent expense on a straight-line basis. No balance sheet recognition of assets or liabilities for operating leases.
Contract asset represents the entity's right to consideration in exchange for goods or services transferred to a customer, before that right becomes unconditional (i.e., before invoice issued).
